description:
Tatsumiyajima is the central island in the middle of a small cluster of islands, in a sleepy backwater of the Japanese isles. Not much happens there, and the island's young people go to school knowing that their lives are likely to remain peaceful and undisturbed. Or so they have been taught... but the truth is different. The fate of mankind is on the line, and Tatsumiyajima is the last line of defense against a hostile and incomprehensible enemy. At the center of it all, fighting for Humanity's continued existence, is the giant robot Fafner, the dragon that guards this final treasure of mankind.

(Source: Anime News Network)

Note: The last episode aired with a runtime of ~48 minutes as opposed to the standard 24 minute long episode. In the DVD release and subsequent home video releases of the series, the final episode was split into two separate ~24 minute long episodes.
synonyms: Fafner in the Azure: Dead Aggressor

tags.name: Philosophy
tags.description: Relating or devoted to the study of the fundamental nature of knowledge, reality, and existence.

tags.name: Ensemble Cast
tags.description: Features a large cast of characters with (almost) equal screen time and importance to the plot.

tags.name: Post-Apocalyptic
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a world or civilization after a global disaster.

tags.name: Real Robot
tags.description: Prominently features mechanical designs loosely influenced by real-world robotics.

tags.name: Tragedy
tags.description: Centers around tragic events and unhappy endings.

tags.name: War
tags.description: Partly or completely set during wartime.

tags.name: Cosmic Horror
tags.description: A type of horror that emphasizes human insignificance in the grand scope of cosmic reality; fearing the unknown and being powerless to fight it.

tags.name: Military
tags.description: Centered around the life and activities of military personnel.

tags.name: Kuudere
tags.description: Prominently features a character who generally retains a cold, blunt and cynical exterior, but once one gets to know them, they have a very warm and loving interior.

tags.name: Dystopian
tags.description: Partly or completely set in a society characterized by poverty, squalor or oppression.

node.description: Ubukata was exposed to a blending of cultures from early childhood until the age of fourteen, having lived in Singapore and Nepal because of his father's work. In 1996, while in college, Ubukata won the first Sneaker Taisho Gold Prize for his light novel Kuroi Kisetsu, and thus debuted as a writer. In 2003, he won the Nihon SF Taisho Award for Mardock Scramble, originally published as a three-volume series. He is involved in a wide range of projects including anime production for Fafner, video game production, and original content writing for comics such as Le Chevalier D'Eon. His other works include the Bye-Bye Earth and Spiegel novel series. In 2009, he published his first historical novel, Tenchi Meisatsu, focusing on a mathematician of the Edo period.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/i/user/31969571)

Originating from [Aubec](https://anilist.co/studio/6090/).

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/平井久司)

__Hisashi Hirai__ is a Japanese animator, designer, illustrator and mangaka. He is best known for his character design work on [Gundam SEED](https://anilist.co/anime/93/Mobile-Suit-Gundam-Seed/) and the Fafner series.

Currently a freelancer. He began his career as an in-betweener for [Nakamura Production](https://anilist.co/studio/6658/Nakamura-Production) and debuted in the 1983 TV series, [Cat's Eye](https://anilist.co/anime/2043/Cats-Eye/). He often worked on many outsourced episodes for [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/Sunrise) shows as a key animator and animation director.

In 1992 he would work on [Dragon Slayer](https://anilist.co/anime/3025/Dragon-Slayer/). An animated adaptation of the 1989 video game Dragon Slayer: The Legend of Heroes by Nihon Falcom, his first major character design credit. Since then, he became more active as a character designer on numerous series. Most notably for Sunrise productions such as [Infinite Ryvius](https://anilist.co/anime/593/Infinite-Ryvius/), [s-CRY-ed](https://anilist.co/anime/168/sCRYed/), and the aforementioned Gundam SEED series; which he had won the Character Design Prize for at the 3rd Tokyo International Anime Fair in 2004.

Hirai is also said to be a close friend of director [Gorou Taniguchi](https://anilist.co/staff/98066/Gorou-Taniguchi).
__Birth Date:__ May 20, 1966

__[Website](http://www.spacecraft.co.jp/saito/) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/斉藤恒芳)__

__Tsuneyoshi Saito__ is a Japanese composer and arranger. He has composed for several anime series, films, and TV dramas.
angela is a Japanese pop band. The main members are Yamashita Atsuko (artist name "atsuko") and Hirasato Katsunori (artist name "KATSU").

[Sakugabooru](https://www.sakugabooru.com/post?tags=naoyuki_konno)

__Naoyuki Konno__ is a Japanese animator and director. He is particularly known for his work on several adaptations of [Shoutarou Ishinomori's](https://anilist.co/staff/97478/Shoutarou-Ishinomori) works as well as his animation style, being renowned as one of the Kanada-school animators.

Noted for her work as a character designer and animation director on numerous anime series.

Learned the ropes studying under [Yoshikazu Yasuhiko](https://anilist.co/staff/97220/). After working as an animator at Kugatsusha, an animation studio led by Yasuhiko, she moved to [Madhouse](https://anilist.co/studio/11/) and provided the character designs for titles such as [Tokyo Babylon](https://anilist.co/anime/1043/), [DNA²](https://anilist.co/anime/563/), [Tetsuwan Birdy](https://anilist.co/anime/566/) as well as the extremely well received mahou shoujo series, [Cardcaptor Sakura](https://anilist.co/anime/232/).

Soon after this Takahashi left Madhouse and teamed up on [Shuukou Murase](https://anilist.co/staff/100793/)'s directorial debut, [Witch Hunter Robin](https://anilist.co/anime/7/) - once again handling the role of character designer. In 2006, she designed the characters for [Ouran High School Host Club](https://anilist.co/anime/853/).

Since then Takahashi has been working exclusively on shows made by either [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/) or [Bones](https://anilist.co/studio/4/).

[Twitter 1](https://twitter.com/i/user/1030757741193646080) | [Twitter 2](https://twitter.com/i/user/1467985113997021188) | [Youtube](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCtOegRvxx7rZNiIsMyEPIfA) | [Website](https://www.hidetoshiohmori19591105.com/)

After graduation, Oomori moved to Tokyo and began his career at Studio Annapuru in 1981, a small sub-contracting studio founded by [Osamu Dezaki](https://anilist.co/staff/100393/) and [Akio Sugino](https://anilist.co/staff/103064/). Soon after he left the studio and joined Bebow, a studio ran by [Tomonori Kogawa](https://anilist.co/staff/105957/). There he mainly worked on mecha shows produced by [Sunrise](https://anilist.co/studio/14/). He also showed up as an animation director on [Urusei Yatsura](https://anilist.co/anime/1293/).

Oomori left Bebow in 1986, and participated in the establishment of Atelier Giga. Around this time he also served as an animation director on [Mobile Suit Gundam: Char's Counterattack](https://anilist.co/anime/87/), one of his best-known works.

In the '90s he was also active in the video game industry. Notably as an animation director on Final Fantasy VII.

Akio Takami is an animator, animation supervisor and character designer. Originally a member of Ashi Productions, he joined Xebec in the 90s, where he participated in most of Xebec's works and became one of the key people at the studio.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/Sunma47) | [Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/三間雅文)

One of the industry's most prolific sound directors, having worked on more than 300 productions.

After having graduated college, Mima joined Magic Capsule, a sound production company ran by his relative [Susumu Aketagawa](https://anilist.co/staff/120062/). In 1986, he debuted as a sound director on [MD Geist](https://anilist.co/anime/1285/MD-Geist/). He left Magic Capsule in 1996, and later joined Techno Sound. In 2004, he became the studio's representative director.

[Twitter](https://twitter.com/gonakanishi)

Gou Nakanishi graduated with a degree from Waseda University's Faculty of Letter's, Arts and Sciences. Starting his career with King Records in 1997, he has been instrumental in developing popular artistes and anime hits such as Sokyuu no Fafner, Inukami and Negima!? He is also the producer of the hit Japanese pop band, angela.

[Wiki (jp)](https://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/高橋晃_(アニメーター%29)

He is an animator and character designer. Motohashi started working at Studio Z. Later, after leaving Studio Z, he started together with Hirayama Satoshi and Kamegaki Hajime Studio Z5. Today he is affiliated with Xebec and is the representative director of its subsidiary Xebec M2.
